Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: This evening, my younger brother called, his voice bubbling with excitement. He’d just been promoted at work, and he wanted the whole family to join him for a spontaneous dinner celebration. As his sister, I knew how much this meant to him. We’d always promised to be there for each other, to cheer each other on at every milestone. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart sank. It was almost dusk—the time I set aside every day to light the lamp and offer prayers at our home altar, a ritual that grounds me in my faith as a Hindu. My mother’s words echoed in my mind: “Never skip your evening prayers, no matter what.” I felt torn, caught between the joy of being a supportive sister and the quiet pull of my spiritual duties. My phone buzzed again with my brother’s message, and I stared at the flickering lamp on the altar, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
